WRITING.TEXT: Notice letters can be really short because they shouldn't actually be used as the primary means of giving notice. Tell your NPs that you need to talk to them and explain that you're resigning, give reasons if appropriate and let them know when your last day will be. If you want to work out any transitional technicalities, this is a good time to bring it up. You can give them the letter as a summary or if you're worried they may later deny what was said in person, but many employees don't even bother with a notice letter at all (even in office jobs, let alone nannying). A sample notice letter can look like this: After three wonderful years with Janie, I #8217;ve made the difficult decision to move on, and March 31 will be my last day. I enjoyed seeing her mature and hope she grows up into a lovely young lady. I am committed to make the transition as smooth as possible. - ParlorPalm That's it! Just three sentences - because you'll say everything else in person.

Do you think you could train to brush her hair better? Like the basics with long hair are to hold on to the top of the strand near your scalp. Then even if you tug on the bottom of the brush, you'll be tugging at the place you're holding, not the scalp. Also, brushing dry hair generally hurts less. Honestly, if she can't brush it herself after that, than she simply can't have that kind of hair. Either a hair dresser can do layers to reduce the volume of hair on her head while preserving the length - or it will just have to be cut shorter. That's going to have to be her parents' decision of course, but as a mom I'd just explain to her that she can't have long hair if she won't brush it. And follow through - cut off a few inches with home scissors the next time she refuses.

What does your teacher's aide job pay you? I'd probably go for a similar or slightly higher rate for nannying, assuming you aren't drastically underpaid there. And yeah, 10-15 seems absolutely ridiculous for two children on the spectrum.

WRITING.TITLE: Obligatory protein question
WRITING.TEXT: Am I getting enough protein? I've heard a lot of vegan sources say that as long as you're getting enough calories on a whole food diet, it's impossible to not have enough protein BUT: Some background info: I've been vegetarian for a while. In September, I started transitioning towards veganism along with some other changes to my lifestyle (I changed jobs, so I have a lot more free time for sleeping, cooking and exercising). So I'm eating about 1800 kcal a day, burning about 2100 (a lot of runnning, no strength training). Went from 75 kg (slightly overweight for my height of 172 cm) to 65 kg (normal weight) and although I can't measure it, the mirror tells me that a lot of fat got replaced with lean muscle (my legs look awesome). Anyways, as I've gradually eliminated most dairy and eggs, I've found my protein intake to be around 35 grams a day. That comes from a lot of roasted veggies (green beans, broccoli, carrots, cauliflower... which are really not that calorie dense though), some beans (I should be eating more... but I just am not), walnuts and some soy milk. Most of my calories come from carbs - vegetables, fruits and whole grains, as well as my sweet tooth for cookies and soda. I googled how much protein I should be eating and sources say 0.8g - 1.2 per kilogram of body weight (so... 52 - 79 g) or 10-35% of calories (so 45 - 158 g). So what about the oft repeated claim that you can't get too little protein on a vegan diet? Well, it works with the claim that you only need 6% of your calories to come from protein. But can someone back that up? Because I haven't seen a single non-vegan source operate with that number and vegan sources aren't sourcing it with scientific studies. I mean, if I really do need to up my protein intake, it wouldn't be hard to do it. But it would mean to moving from beans 2-3 times a week to everyday, cooking with soy and it's just a bit annoying. So do I really need to? And if so, what are your favourite hassle-free sources :) ? Like if I wanted to get 50g with my beloved green beans, I'd need to eat 3 kilograms of them. And that's a high-protein veg!

I think you're right. I think I was kind of hoping for a "oh, you're fine", but you're right. I'm just going to have to learn to cook with beans and pulses, because I didn't eat them as an omni. I think the issue is that I've basically replaced most of my animal products with veggies, which means that my meals are too low calories and I do reach for sweets as a snack since I get hungry. But as you said - pulses are easy - I just need to get used to them. Sorry if it seems like I'm working through really obvious stuff, I'm sure I'll figure it all out, but I guess I'm still mentally stuck in a meat-based mealplan just omitting the meat... and that's obviously not working.

Yeah, that sounds like an offer you can't refuse. As zahcncam said, do make sure you have an unconditional offer before you resign. Congratulations and don't feel guilty for moving on - this is the best decision for you. I know that nannying is personal, but at the end of the day, it's an employment relationship where you're trading services for money. If the nanny parents got the opportunity to change jobs for a huge pay increase, they'd take it - and their employer wouldn't be 'devastated, hurt and betrayed'. It's just a normal part of working relationships. I would, however, say to the new family: "If it's possible, I'd like to give my current family 2-3 weeks notice as a professional courtesy, so I would start on [X]. Would that timeline work for you?"

WRITING.TITLE: How do you put on a bra?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm not joking \- I'm 24 and have realised I've been putting on a bra wrong my whole life. When I was 12 and had my first bra, my older sister taught me to wrap it around my waist, secure the hooks in front, spin it and pull it up. Went for a bra fitting yesterday, apparently, you're supposed to slip into the straps first and hook it behind you \- which has you get a better fit on which clasp to use. Ugh! And I just can't \- I am physically unable to secure the hooks if I don't see them. For sports bras \(which can't be hooked in front and spun because they have criss cross straps\) I've just been buying ones with a zip in the front. How do you put it on? Does hooking in the back become easier with practice? How do normal people put on bras with criss cross straps? So many questions!
I guess that depends on your body type. My waist is smaller than my ribcage, so I have no problem spinning it there even though it's tight once I get it to where it's supposed to be.
I can unclasp them from behind, so I generally unclasp first and then slide out. If I'm drunk or really tired however, I regress to sliding out, pushing down and spinning :\)
It's more dexterity. I can reach there and even unclasp it without issue \- but I just can't get the hooks to go in the right place if I don't see them.
I also want to clarify that my motor skills in general are not great \- never learnt how to sew or throw a ball, so that may have something to do with it :D

I would be vary of them. Insurance is a binding contract, where the insurance company is obligated to pay out in predefined situations. If an insurance company rejects your claim, you have legal recourse. The insurance industry is extremely regulated and insurance companies are subject to strict solvency criteria (making sure the company has enough money to pay out claims). Health ministries are not the same as insurance. Smaller claims are not going to be an issue, but if you have a really expensive issue - think cancer - you have no guarantee they'll actually be willing to pay out or have sufficient funds to do so. Google Pastor Andy Bowman whose bills for heart disease were denied.

Most freelancers have a higher rate for short term gigs. Say you want to earn 200 bucks a day. If you have a client with a large project, you just charge them 25/h, easy. But it's probably a lot harder to do 8 one-hour jobs in one day - think about commuting to client sites (eg. this lady's home), having to coordinate times (what if two of your clients want a 9 am meeting) etc. So for example, a freelancer might charge 25/h to a big client, but 35/h to someone who just wants a small one-off job. Thing is, the woman has this all wrong. First of all, you can't have the rates be 5 and 10 dollars respectively - it's just far too low. Second, these terms are negotiated between the parties, not set unilaterally by the customer. Third - the lady's just insane!

Adoption is a wonderful thing, but I'd be vary of suggesting it as a way to make parenting easier. Thing is, adoption is by definition preceded by trauma - at the very minimum, there's separation from the biological parents and then there's also the reason for separation. A toddler or school aged child with a history of trauma isn't some Anne of Green Gables fairytale. They've been through a lot and need a lot of support and informed parenting to deal with that. Parenting techniques that worked on your non-traumatised kids might not work. Check out r/fosterit and r/Adoption to find out that parenting a traumatised non-verbal and non-potty trained 6-yo is far tougher than a (non-verbal and non-potty trained) baby! The OP mentions being open to adoption on its own merits and that's absolutely wonderful. I encourage you to learn more about it, but just keep in mind that it presents its own challenges.

I feel for you. For me it wasn't the taste itself: sure I liked cheese, but I could overcome that, but more its omnipresence and convenience in our lives. What specifically are you eating and when? Milk itself was easy - just pick up a carton of Alpro instead of dairy and you're all set. Cheese used to be my go to sandwich filler, so I stocked up on hummus and vegan spreads. Put a tub of Alpro ice cream or sorbet in your freezer for when you want ice cream. Basically, if you have plenty of delicious food at home, you won't bother running to the store for dairy, so just stock up on vegan products. It's okay if you eat a bit of vegan junk food during your transition. For me, the challenge was eating out. If I'm going out with friends and there's nowhere with actual vegan options, we go for pizza and I ask for the cheese to be left off (do check the crust: all my local places have a vegan crust, but I've heard some US chains shove dairy in there).

I wouldn't call almond milk healthy - it has far less protein than soy (or cow) milk. Almonds are expensive, so commercial almond milks have more sugar than almonds. If you make it yourself, you can control the sugar, but then you're losing out on the fortifications. I mean, almond milk can certainly be part of a healthy diet if most of your other foods are unprocessed, and the other reasons for cutting out dairy are enough, but I'm struggling to find a criterion by which almond milk can be considered healthy. It's sweetened water!
Almond milk doesn't have a lot of almonds so the water footprint isn't that bad.
Yeah, but Alpro unsweetened almond milk has a whopping 2% of almonds. Nutritionally, it's equivalent to drinking a glass of water and taking a calcium pill.

Oh yeah, I'm not saying people shouldn't be drinking it - it's delicious and cruelty free. But the poster is factually incorrect - it's the same like the infographics claiming broccoli has more protein than beef. Sure, not eating beef is still the right thing to do but what does that have to do with lying?
So what ingredient in almond milk makes it healthy?

Sure it isn't. But the comparison between sugar (not carbs generally, but the added sugar in almond milk) and soybean protein is pretty clear. So in which nutrients does almond milk fare better than soy?

I don't see much of a point in comparing them. Talk to her, agree on quiet hours (11pm - 7am? - depends on your schedules) during which neither of you will play music, make phones calls or watch stuff without headphones. More likely than not, she will be glad you told her instead of silently resenting her. Here's a script I suggest, but feel free to use whatever wording you want: "Hey Linda, I was wondering if we could agree on set quiet hours for the room. I'm really sensitive to noise and while I totally get you want to facetime your boyfriend, I was wondering whether we could agree on no calls and music after 11 PM." In situations like this, I always try to play the "it's not you, it's me card" - like saying you're really sensitive to noise/light or obsessive about cleanliness... I think it protects the other person's feelings. Get noise cancelling headphones even if she agrees to quiet hours - they are a necessity when sharing a room. Also keep in mind that she's probably feeling a little homesick and lonely right now. It's unlikely she'll keep doing this once she makes new friends and is busy with classes and extracurriculars. But it's better to raise this now, rather then telling her half way through the year or requesting a room change. If I was doing something that annoyed my roommate, I'd want to know - not find out months later!

So, from what I've **read**, your body doesn't really lose the ability to digest meat, so a few bites should be absolutely fine from a digestive viewpoint. Of course, you might be so repelled by the idea that you've consumed flesh, that you'll throw up psychosomatically (the way an omni might if they learned they had just eaten human). But honestly, what I've read didn't really match up with my **lived experience**. My journey towards veganism began with environmental concerns, so to start, I limited myself to just one meat containing meal a week (looking back, I can see I was a bit of a idiot for not going all the way, but nevermind that). So I'd eat veggie for the week and then indulge myself with a beef burger Sunday nights or some chicken wings. After just two months of this reductarian diet however, I started having GI issues with that one meat meal. Sometimes, they'd come immediately, other times it would take a while. After three consecutive Mondays when I'd come into work and head straight into the bathroom to violently vomit, I went full vegetarian. I'm not sure what was happening there - I mean, limiting meat shouldn't make you unable to digest it (afterall, before the 20th century in the west, most people would eat meat once a week at most because it was a luxury)... but my body was sending me some pretty clear signals and so I obeyed.

Like everyone says, weight gain is caused by eating more calories than you burn. It's true that a vegan diet can often be lower in calories than an omni one, because you cut out a lot of foods with really high calorie content (think lard, butter, bacon or cheese) , but it's completely possible to overeat and underexercise as a vegan. It's a lot easier to overeat on white rice and white bread than on whole grains, because there's less fibre, so you feel less full. So buying only brown rice, wholegrain bread and pasta is one of the easiest changes you can make to be healthier. If you want, go ahead and post what you typically eat in a day/week + height + weight + activity level and we'll be happy to help find the best place to cut calories.

With plastic, not really. There's more collected recyclable plastic than there is demand for it. Plastic can only be downcycled: once you recycle a clear coca cola bottle, you can't make that clear, shiny plastic from it - you can only make a worse looking bottle (or foil or a plastic bag or something). Coca cola for instance, has refused to use recycled plastic for its bottles, because it wouldn't look as nice. Recycling matters most with glass and metal: you can basically melt and reuse these materials over and over again.

I found it interesting that you say that all the sophomores look like 12 year olds :) I mean, if all the sophomores look like 12 year olds, maybe our perception of who "looks 12" is wrong. When 15-year-olds are played by 25-year olds and 10-year-olds are played by 15-year-olds, our perception of what people look like at a certain age get skewed. The result is that you think that every single sophomore looks like they're 12, but it's just that 12-year-olds on screen are played by high school sophomores. For example, Caleb McLaughlin is 16, but plays 12-year old Lucas in Stranger Things - so we slowly get the idea that pre-teens look like Caleb McLaughlin... when they really don't. That's not great for body image issues - TV characters are often role models, but it's hard for teens to understand why their bodies don't look like what they see on TV.

There's nothing unhealthy about GMOs, plant breeding has been safely done since pre-industrial times. There are however some ecological issues: decrease in biodiversity, incidents of plants "escaping" the fields and taking root in other fields or natural environments, as well as an increase in secondary pests. I haven't done enough research to decide whether these outweigh the ecological advantages of GMOs (needs less soil for the same amount of food, decreases pesticide use by being pest-resistant), so I do eat them. Wheareas with animal products, their ecological impact is pretty obviously catastrophic. #8203; It's just another way the public has been brainwashed into "oh no, GMO corn is unnatural"... while eating hormone filled flesh.

Eh, I know I'm going to get downvoted for this, but it's possible to be a specieist and vegan. I don't eat animal products because the suffering and ecological impact is wholly unnecessary, thus unjustifiable. There's no need for steak or cheese, so causing insane pain to beings who are not quite human - but still very sentient, smart and capable of love and suffering is unethical. But if we're talking about situations where it really is the life of a human versus an animal life - eg. pig heart valves are often transplanted to humans with cardiac dysfunction - I'm going to choose the human life. It's just that such situations are very rare, despite what omnis would argue constitutes their "needs".

I'm obviously not saying vegetarianism is great, but depending on how you do it, it can be better than a omni diet. First of all, the dairy industry is obviously terrible. But a dairy cow (count in two dead calves) produces 24 000 litres of milk in a lifetime, which is more dairy based meals than the 500 kg of beef from one. A laying hen will produce about 450 eggs in a lifetime, versus a few kilograms of meat. Counting it as meals per death, vegetarianism is generally better than a meat based diet. Counting it in terms of C02 emissions shows the same conclusion. An Average American #8217;s diet has a foodprint of around 2.5 t CO2e per person each year. For the Vegetarian it #8217;s 1.7 t CO2e and for the Vegan it is 1.5 t CO2e. Each of these estimates includes emissions from food that is eaten, wasted by consumers and lost in the supply chain. http://shrinkthatfootprint.com/food-carbon-footprint-diet And secondly, most vegetarians I know don't just sub in a block of cheese for meat at every meal. They're actively trying to reduce the amount of animal products they eat, but maybe still want to be able to go get a weekly pizza with friends or not worry about that 0,2% milk powder in potato chips. Vegetarianism is a lot easier than veganism, yet still brings some benefit.

Ok. I understand your frustration. The cumulative effect of months of sleep deprivation is terrible - I've been there due to a noisy water heater and it's a horrible thing. The thing is, I think you've reached "Bitch Eating Crackers" stage with your roommate. What's that? Once you hate someone, everything they do is offensive: "Look at this bitch eating those crackers like she owns the place." It's not OK that they moved in their boyfriend for free, it's not OK that they selected the new roommate without any input from you. But it's also none of your business that they don't work, their mom covers their bills or that they're "abusing their freedom". You're upset about these issues because you're sleep deprived and frustrated about the other things, but they're actually not anything wrong in themselves - or at least not wrong in ways that are of your concern. It's unreasonable for you to police a "curfew" for your roommate. They are entitled to come home when they want and microwave a simple meal. But at the same time, you are entitled to a room where you can sleep. Go ahead, ask for the boyfriend to cover part of the utilities. Push back on your ex moving in. But most importantly - find a way to isolate the noise. This has to be poor house design - it's really not normal for someone on a different floor to hear the fridge door open. Look into soundproofing the place: even a sliding door can make a huge difference. I'm not saying you're wrong, but the solution here isn't to set a curfew for your roommate.

A "rodn #233; #269; #237;slo" is assigned to citizens (at birth) and to foreigners (upon request) by the Ministry of Interior. If you have temporary residency, you should be able to find this number on your ID card. If you have a " #382;ivnostensk #253; list", it should be mentioned in the decision. Basically, if it has already been assigned, it will be on most official paper work - the rodn #233; #269; #237;slo is a general identifier used not only by VZP, but basically by all state institutions. You mention your date of birth. If you are male, your rodn #233; #269; #237;slo will start with 820728. If you are female, your rodn #233; #269; #237;slo will start with 825728. However, I can't tell you the last four digits, as they are randomly assigned by the ministry. Fun fact: All rodn #225; #269; #237;sla are divisible by 11!

I believe the purpose is to make it easier to spot errors. If I make a mistake or typo when filling out a form, or if a government officer makes that mistake when inputting data in a database, it's pretty unlikely that the mistake will be a valid rodn #233; #269; #237;slo belonging to someone else.

Depends. Customer service can mean a lot of things - from entry level inbound call centre work to client management. Relocation expenses are also really dependant on circumstances. I'd expect the company to pay if I was being transferred within the same company or if they reached out to me first, asking if I would be open to moving for their job. If you have a skill set that's in high demand, you can get relocation assistance even if that isn't the case: for example, relocation assistance is practically standard in IT. Or if OP has say, some special skills or niche languages (like Dutch or Chinese). But if a company has good local candidates, they have no reason to offer relocation expenses just because a candidate chooses to apply from abroad. And generally, junior positions are easier to fill, there's less of a need to find the perfect candidate (as opposed to just good enough). Few companies I know would pay for relocation expenses for something as generic as a junior customer service position, if the foreign languages are common (German, English...).

I get what you're saying: cheese and cured meats are already done, so just add it to literally anything and it's satisfying. But after a while, you learn how to cook vegan and it becomes very simple as well (have a few simple recipes and just rotate the veggies). You can cheat with fake meats, smoked tempeh, etc. And for beginning cooks, one huge advantage of cooking vegan is that the risk of food poisoning is much lower. If you undercook meat or eggs, you are in for salmonella. If you undercook veggies or tofu, it might taste a bit bland. Same goes for leaving it out a bit too long after cooking or refreezing... really scary with meat, no big deal with vegan ingredients.

There's a point to the accredited vegan signs regulated by national vegan societies. Even if you read the ingredient list, that doesn't tell you whether a certain additive was derived from plant or animal sources (vitamin D for instance can come from animals or moss/fungi/seaweed; glycerids can be obtained from animal fat or vegetable oils) or if an animal product was used during filtering a liquid (wines and juices are often filtered through gelatin, but since it doesn't stay in the drink it doesn't have to be disclosed). I personally have decided to just buy such items anyway, because well, my veganism is more a utilitarian than an absolutist stance. But it's unfortunate that even reading labels isn't enough if you want to be a purist.

I feel the word plant based is a bit unfortunate. The actual meaning is a diet that excludes all animal products, but if you haven't heard it before, you'll just interpret it as "based on plants". But "based on plants" doesn't actually exclude all animal products. Look at these examples of similar phrases: * If a movie is "based on a true story" you know that something similar actually happened, but there's definitely an artistic license. * Evidence-based medicine relies on research on why a treatment works, but it also takes patient preferences into account. * Inquiry-based learning starts by asking questions, but that doesn't mean other methods can't be used in the classroom at all. * A competency-based job interview will involve a practical exercise (like solve this problem, write a sample), but that doesn't mean it won't include talking about working hours and pay. So if I were just guessing what plant based means, I'd assume that it's mostly plants but wouldn't automatically rule out small amounts of animal products. That's not how the word is actually used, but I think the label maker might have been more ignorant than malicious.

Honestly, if it's this bad I'd consider a vegan meal replacement shake. Huel in the UK, but I'm sure there's an American equivalent. I used it for a bit as a student with limited access to kitchen, although I eventually just found it more satisfying to cook for myself. But if the idea of cooking every meal from scratch is so daunting, it might be a start. Nobody enjoys doing things they're not good at. But the more you cook, the easier it will get and the more enjoyable. Here's some convenience meals that don't really require cooking. Maybe just try cooking a couple of times a week and use a replacement shake for the rest. Now, they're not super-duper-ultra-healthy, but for me, they are convenient enough: \- Cooking veggies seems difficult and they come out soggy? Fine. Buy oil in a mist spray bottle, buy the veggies in a frozen medley, buy an "italian herb mix". Put down a sheet of baking paper, spread out the frozen veggies, spray with oil, season. Roast in the oven on 180 celsius for twenty minutes. If you have enough broccolli in there, this can actually be a main meal, but add a faux meat (vegan sausage or burger) if you want. \- Baked beans. Yeah, they have sodium, but they're still really nutritious. \- Cous cous doesn't really require "cooking" per se. Buy whole grain, put it in a pot and pour over with water (1 part water to 2 part cous cous). In a seperate pan, put a block of frozen spinach, some more frozen veggies and just cook until hot. Use your spice mix, a little salt, add to the cous cous. Done. #8203; I think you get the picture. It's daunting to just start cooking from scratch. But there's plenty of "cheats" in the kitchen with frozen and canned veggies or faux meats that are way better for you than fries. Now eventually, you'll realise that cleaning and cutting veggies is a piece of cake. But for me, starting with a kilo bag of frozen medley was a life saver.

Lawyer here. In theory, the company could sue you for damages caused by breach of contract - such as the costs of hiring a contractor to cover the work or the cost of losing a client since they could no longer deliver the promised workproduct on time. However, this doesn't really happen in practice, because it's extremely difficult for the employer to prove the damages and courts tend to side with employees anyway. But I still wouldn't recommend leaving without notice, as it will be devastating to your professional reputation. Forget about ever getting a reference from the place and expect that if your former coworkers move on to different companies, you will likely be blacklisted there as well. Most employees don't want a disgruntled employee showing up to work anyways, so you can always see if you can agree on an earlier end date. If not, I'd suck it up unless the situation is really bad.
That's not just your company, it's section 51 of the Labour Code.

It's just the economics. Currently, a farmer who rapes a cow and kills her baby makes $ X for the milk and $Y for the meat. If nobody wants the milk, you will probably send the cow to slaughter earlier or lower the price of the milk so that someone is more likely to buy it. Therefore, the farmer might make only $ X-500 for the milk. At that point, several things can happen - farmer will go out of business or veal prices will rise accordingly (thus lowering demand) and over time, the whole industry gets smaller and less profitable. BUT that's actually pretty optimistic and a ceteris paribus theoretical model. Overall, the world is getting richer and consuming more and more meat, just because it can afford to. Look at the latest USDA reports that show that US meat consumption is continuously rising. Milk - as in cartons - is declining, but products like yogurt and cheese are going strong. It's super complicated and hard to predict what exactly will happen with animal product consumption in our lifetimes.
As I've explained, dairy is essentially subsidising the cost of veal at the moment. Less demand for milk - gt; less veal.

WRITING.TITLE: "No Good Nick" is such a bad show
WRITING.TEXT: No Good Nick popped up on my Netflix, so I gave it a shot. It's truly a despicable depiction of the kids in the foster care system. The basic premise is that the main character Nicole ("Nick") enters the foster care system after her dad ends up in prison. Her foster parents are con artists and so they set up a scam where she pretends to be a long lost relative of a wealthy family, who takes her in. Cue shenanigangs to steal the wealthy family's money, of course mixed in with sacharine sweet scenes when she realises she actually grows to love the family she set out to scam. I don't even know where to begin about everything that's wrong with the show. It paints foster kids as street smart scammers. It doesn't address a single point about trauma or attachment. It paints foster parents as con artists, but with a strange soft spot for the children they exploit. It paints the foster care system as completely incompetent on one hand, but unreasonably overprotective on the other. There's a whole episode where the SSO is slipped a fake file, so they believe that Nicole is meant to live with the wealthy family, but they send over a family therapist who threatens to remove her for not opening up enough. #8203; I mean, it's a sitcom. It doesn't have to be comprehensive or a 100 % realistic depiction. But it shouldn't pander to the worst stereotypes out there!
Thanks for the tip :) at least from the reviews, it looks like a much better show :)
Media representation influences reality. Our understanding of the world is socially constructed. Present foster kids as bad on TV, create hostility towards them in real life.

I feel just a bit of cringe here - it's as if your parents felt they were doing a charitable act by spending time with the girl. I appreciate her much more than my sister seems to. ") I think that your sister should treat her roommate basically the same way she'd treat a neurotypical roommate. And it's perfectly normal not to want to spend every waking moment with your roommate or to not invite them to a family dinner! Sheesh!

I think the main issue here is that your parents seem overinvolved in your sister's life. Part of going away to college is learning how to live like an adult and figure these things out on their own. Of course she's responsible for cleaning up after herself, but she's no longer a five-year-old being forced into chores with a sticker chart. She needs to be given an opportunity to take care of herself without your parents' intervention. And her relationship with her roommate is really up to her. Of course, she SHOULD be courteous, kind and respectful: but she's an adult and your parents don't get to police that anymore. And I'm going to repeat that there's no obligation to go beyond that common courtesy - you don't have to be best friends with your roommate and her autism doesn't change anything about that.

If you lie beforehand, you'll establish a hostile relationship with your landlord, who can terminate your contract with a three month notice (there's some conditions, but again, easy to circumvent in practice). So I'd just be honest and find a landlord's who is ok with it.

I'd trust your doctors. I mean, your symptoms are so generic it could be anything (I had basically the same symptoms, it was WPW syndrome and required surgery), but if your doctors say it's not serious, believe them. I suggest you start with C25k which starts you off with switching running-walking. If it triggers your arrythmia, you can just briskly walk - what's important is that you keep moving. The heart is a muscle, exercise will do it good.

My symptoms were the worst in my teenage years, but nothing showed up on an ECG or a 24-hour-heart-rate monitor. By my mid-twenties, my palpitations were much less frequent but it happened to show up on a routine ECG and it just so happened the cardiologist I was referred to specialised in arrythmia. The WPW was clear from the ECG, I had an ultrasound done as general due diligence before the surgery itself. I had an ablation (which is a very minor surgery) and I've been symptom-free ever since. However, irregular heart beat is a very general symptom and no one here is qualified to give you medical advice. My WPW was more of an example - it really could be anything. And an important note, I had been running for a couple of years before the surgery itself. I did have a few times where I had to stop because of the arrythmia, but overall it was fine. Exercise is good for your cardiovascular health.
Well, OP has already seen multiple doctors. So the answer changes to: trust them.

I live in Prague and I run pretty much year round. Running really warms you up, so long leggins and a light fleece or wind breaker are fine even when it hits below zero. Get gloves - even cheap cotton ones are fine. You might need another layer since you're used to warmer temperatures. Running in the winter is awesome. Everything looks so peaceful and parks aren't as crowded. It's infinitely easier to run in the cold than in the summer heat anyways. I'm actually more surprised you manage to run outside year round in Australia. However, I don't run on ice. It's not impossible to do but I really wouldn't recommend it if you aren't used to it (and since you won't have the right shoes). If it does get icey (which it might not at all, depends on the year and where you'll be at the time of the worst winter cold), I suggest you just find a gym. Incidentally, gyms are affordable in Prague - about 8 euros for a day pass.
Most sidewalks in major cities are too narrow and crowded to accommodate runners. Parks and trails (a lot of cities have nice trails along a river) are the way to go.

From Wikipedia: While he confessed to 27 murders, only nine could be plausibly confirmed and **several of the people he claimed to have murdered were still alive. He is said to have killed as many as 200, though this figure is only traceable to 1940s pulp magazines.** Many victims were said to have been killed in a mixed-use building which he owned, located about 3 miles (5 km) west of the 1893 World's Fair: Columbian Exposition, supposedly called the World's Fair Hotel (informally called "The Murder Castle"), **though evidence suggests the hotel portion was never truly open for business.** Besides being a serial killer, Holmes was also a con artist and a bigamist, the subject of more than 50 lawsuits in Chicago alone. Many now-common stories of his crimes sprang from fictional accounts that later authors assumed to be factual. In a 2017 biography, Adam Selzer wrote that Holmes' story is "effectively a new American tall tale #8211; and, like all the best tall tales, it sprang from a kernel of truth".\[3\]

Hi :) Roommate living has its pros and cons, but I definitely think the savings are worth it. Basically, my advice is to "interview" your roommates - insist on meeting everyone to have a nice friendly chat and see if you click. All of the things you ask work differently depending on the flatshare arrangement and you should ask about them before picking a flat. But here are some general thoughts based on my experience: \- Kitchen: in my flat, we share basics like oil, ketchup or coffee. We each have our section of the fridge and separate cabinets for everything else. One disadvantage is that you have to be a bit more diligent about cleaning up right away, because any messes will prevent others from using the kitchen. \- Guests: Having someone over occasionally is not a problem, but it shouldn't be an extra non-paying roommate. My rule of thumb is no more than 4 consecutive days and no more than 8 days in a calendar month. And of course, things change significantly during shelter-in-place orders - then you can't have anyone over. Overall, I'm really happy to have one roommate. It's a perfect balance between privacy and companionship and between space and money. Feel free to ask any more questions!

WRITING.TITLE: Henry's change of heart (spoilers)
WRITING.TEXT: So what spurs Henry's change from "don't call me unless someone's injured" to "I love you, let's move to America together"? Let's be clear, Henry fails in his basic duties as a guardian. He leaves the children in a vacation home in the middle of nowhere. He doesn't try very hard to hire an au-pair, so most of the time, the kids are cared for by the housekeeper (who has other things to do). Flora doesn't attend school at all in the two years following her parents' death (though she did so before, Mrs. Grose asks her about her year when she arrives with her parents to Bly). And it would have been so easy to be a better guardian without major lifestyle changes on Henry's part - move the kids to London (where they probably used to live anyway, Bly was just a vacation home), hire a nanny there and send the kids to a posh day school (there's plenty of them in London). Oh, and get them therapy. The banishing from Bly doesn't seem to have been paranormal, he is able to return without any issues in the finale. This feels like a major logic gap in the show and it's not the only one. The inconsistencies abound.
Jamie is retelling a lot that she couldn't have possibly known! Miles' departure from school, Rebecca and Peter's relationship, Peter's memories...

I didn't miss it - it's beaten to death in the series. I just don't see how breaking up someone else's marriage justifies not sending kids to school or how this guilt magically disappears in one night.
